item.title: Nagorno-Karabakh: Armenia-Azerbaijan truce broken minutes after deal
item.description: Each accuses the other of violating a humanitarian ceasefire agreed on Saturday.

item.title: Coronavirus: Empty streets in France as curfew enforced
item.description: The overnight curfew in nine cities is aimed at curbing the soaring Covid infection rate in France.

item.title: France teacher attack: Suspect 'asked pupils to point Samuel Paty out'
item.description: The man waited for Samuel Paty, who showed Prophet Muhammad cartoons in class, and beheaded him.

item.title: Lesbos: What really happened in the refugee camp destroyed by flames?
item.description: BBC Newsnight looks into the origins of the fire that destroyed Europe's largest refugee camp.

item.title: London Bridge attack: Steven Gallant up for early release after confronting knifeman
item.description: Convicted murderer Steven Gallant was on day release when he helped stop a knifeman's rampage.

item.title: Bolivia election: Five things to know about
item.description: The re-run of the controversial presidential election in 2019 has been tensely awaited.

item.title: US woman faces first federal execution since 1953
item.description: Lisa Montgomery is due to become the first woman to face federal execution in the US in 67 years.

item.title: Brexit: Door 'still ajar' for EU trade talks, says Gove
item.description: The UK will continue to engage but only if the EU changes its position in key areas, says Michael Gove.

item.title: Guinea elections: Alpha Condé takes on Cellou Dalein Diallo again
item.description: A divisive new constitution allows Alpha Condé to stand again, amid political and ethnic tensions.

item.title: Vietnam landslide: Rescuers search for survivors at barracks
item.description: The huge landslide buried 22 soldiers as the country battles its worst floods for years.

item.title: Pakistan stops bid to smuggle endangered falcons
item.description: The falcons are on the endangered species list and are said to be worth almost £1m.

item.title: Coronavirus: Dutch royals return amid anger over Covid holiday
item.description: The family flew back from Greece after just a day on holiday there, amid intense criticism.

item.title: I won't give up - Hong Kong activist 'Grandma Wong'
item.description: Alexandra Wong tells reporters she was detained in mainland China and forced to renounce her activism.

item.title: Thailand protests: Thousands rally for third straight day despite government ban
item.description: Many are angry that the authorities used water cannon to disperse protesters on Friday.

item.title: Climate change: Arctic Circle teens call for help to save their homes
item.description: Teenagers living in remote Arctic communities share their concerns about the effects of climate change.

item.title: Philippines: Environmentalists criticise artificial beach in Manila Bay
item.description: There is controversy over a new artificial beach in the Philippine capital, Manila, made from crushed dolomite rock which some people say is bad for the environment.

item.title: Beirut protests: 'A year of rising and fading hopes'
item.description: The BBC's Lina Sinjab looks back at one year of protests calling for change in Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Your pictures on the theme of 'life in the water'
item.description: A selection of pictures from our readers on the theme of "life in the water".

item.title: ICYMI: Robot dolphins and a skeleton worth millions
item.description: Some of the stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: Hundreds queue in Yiwu, China for experimental Covid-19 vaccine
item.description: The vaccine is available to the public in the city of Yiwu but is still in the final trial stages.

item.title: Azerbaijan at war: Reporter’s journal
item.description: A BBC team spent a week looking at the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict from the Azerbaijani side.

item.title: US election: Are white women voters wavering on Trump?
item.description: Polls suggest they're changing their minds on the president. We look at what impact it could have.

item.title: Week in pictures: 10-16 October 2020
item.description: A selection of striking images taken around the world this week.

item.title: Jacinda Ardern's key leadership moments
item.description: A look back at the New Zealand prime minister's first term in office.

item.title: Parkour group marks 10 years on YouTube with 6.5m subscribers
item.description: The Sussex parkour group STORROR is celebrating a decade on YouTube and a job in a Hollywood film.

item.title: Why the US election could decide battle against climate change
item.description: Who next occupies the White House could be decisive in the battle to limit global warming.

item.title: ‘I hugged the man who murdered my father’
item.description: Candice Mama's father was killed by a man nicknamed "Prime Evil", yet the only way she could find peace was to forgive him.

item.title: US election 2020: Lives that could be reshaped by Supreme Court
item.description: One law, 10 years on, and 23 million Americans whose healthcare access could soon change.

item.title: Thailand protests: 'My father is blinded by his love for the monarchy'
item.description: Young Thais are falling out with their parents over calls to reform an institution seen as untouchable.

item.title: Jacinda Ardern's majority may prove to be her biggest challenge
item.description: Jacinda Ardern may find it hard to reconcile the demands of her disparate voters, says columnist Josh Van Veen.

item.title: How smart devices are exploited for domestic abuse
item.description: Two women explain how their partners turned internet-connected gadgets into a means of control.

item.title: Lebanon protesters' euphoria gives way to despair
item.description: The country's problems have worsened since huge crowds took to the streets a year ago.

item.title: End Sars: How Nigeria's anti-police brutality protests went global
item.description: Why did Nigerian protests against police brutality gain international attention and support?

item.title: Ammonite: Who was the real Mary Anning?
item.description: In a romantic Victorian-era drama, Kate Winslet plays the role of fossilist Mary Anning. Who was she?

item.title: Champions Cup: Does dynasty beckon for Exeter after historic European win?
item.description: After clinching their first Champions Cup, could the next 10 years eclipse even Exeter's previous decade?

item.title: Virgil van Dijk injury is not good, says Jurgen Klopp after Liverpool draw with Everton
item.description: Liverpool defender Virgil van Dijk's knee injury is "not good", says the champions' manager Jurgen Klopp.

item.title: Promoted Cadiz earn shock win over Real Madrid to draw level at top
item.description: Newly promoted Cadiz stun defending champions Real Madrid with a deserved victory that moves them level at the top of La Liga.

item.title: Tampa Bay Rays beat Houston Astros to reach World Series for second time
item.description: The Tampa Bay Rays reach the World Series for only the second time with a 4-2 game-seven win over the Houston Astros.

item.title: What is the big picture for English football now after turbulent week?
item.description: BBC sports editor Dan Roan examines the fallout from an extraordinary week which started with Project Big Picture and ended with more questions.

item.title: Man Utd's season starts now - Solskjaer after comeback win
item.description: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer says Manchester United's season starts now after "inspirational" captain Harry Maguire led a comeback win at Newcastle.

item.title: The rape survivors facing an ‘impossible choice’ in Brazil
item.description: Covid and new rules have made access to legal terminations even more difficult for Brazilian women.

item.title: Hidden camera's hugging tiger wins wildlife photo award
item.description: A camera-trap image of an Amur tiger takes the grand prize at Wildlife Photographer of the Year 2020.

item.title: Cougar stalk: Utah jogger on six-minute encounter with a mountain lion
item.description: A jog on his local trail turned into a life-or-death situation for Kyle Burgess in Utah.

item.title: South Africa: Is 'black tax' help or a burden?
item.description: Young professionals in South Africa discuss the expectation to financially support their families.
